Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of deaths from the flu compared to COVID-19.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that there have been more deaths from the flu than from COVID-19.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that comparing deaths from the flu to COVID-19 is an equitable comparison, disregarding the differences in reporting and tracking methods.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim overlooks the data from the expert's home state, which shows more COVID-19 deaths than flu deaths, suggesting an alternative explanation.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not considering the timing of the entry of flu and COVID-19 into the US, which affects the comparison of deaths.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that as of April 25, more than 50,000 people had died from COVID-19, according to the CDC.
Understate: The claim understates the severity of COVID-19 by comparing it to the flu and downplaying its impact.
